Award.AwardTitle: Optical Carrier Based Microwave Interferometry for Spatially Continuous Distributed Monitoring of Structural Health

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to develop robust, embeddable, distributed sensors for structural health monitoring (SHM) to ensure continuing safe operations of the nation's critical infrastructures. Based on the novel concept of optical carrier based microwave interferometry (OCMI), the developed sensors have the long-desired high measurement resolution for studying structural behaviors under normal loads, the large strain capability for diagnosing the structural integrity under extreme loads, and the spatial continuity (no dark zones) over a large span for comprehensive evaluation of the health status of the structure as a whole. The fundamental physics of OCMI will be studied to understand its full capabilities for sensing applications. The various engineering options will be explored to formulate an optimal design for maximized distributed sensing capability. Polymer optical fiber (POF) based OCMI sensors will be designed, developed and characterized for distributed measurement of large strain and crack detection to demonstrate the effectiveness of the new OCMI concept for SHM.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to an enabling SHM technology to ensure the safe operation of the nation's deteriorating infrastructures, and facilitate mission-critical services during disaster responses and emergency evacuations. The research will establish an insight understanding to design integrated microwave-optics systems for various sensing needs. Distributed crack detection and quantification will be implemented using flexible and robust POF based OCMI sensors with enhanced deployability, embeddability, reliability and large strain capability. The fundamental knowledge and methodologies developed in this research are also transferrable to other critical applications in SHM such as distributed monitoring of force, load, fatigue and corrosion.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits

This project aimed to uncover the full potentials of a new sensing technology, the optical carrier-based microwave interferometry (OCMI), for structural health monitoring (SHM).  The essence of OCMI is to read optical interferometers using microwave. It combines the strengths of both optics and microwave to offer a number of unique advantages for SHM. The fundamental research conducted in this project allow us to fill the capability gaps and provide a novel sensing technology to ensure continuing safe operation of the nation’s critical infrastructures. The technical accomplishments are highlighted below:

1) Comprehend the fundamental physics of OCMI to harvest the full advantages. The mathematic models and simulations have been established to study the dynamic and static responses of the system. Experiments were carried up to validate the models and simulation results. Our theoretical and experimental studies have proven the unique advantages of OCMI including: 1) high measurement resolution, 2) distributed sensing with spatial continuity and reconfigurable gauge length, 3) insensitivity to the types of optical waveguides, 4) insensitivity to polarization variations, and 5) relieved fabrication requirements. These unique advantages have the full shown the potential to fill the capability gaps.

2) Formulate the engineering designs to achieve maximal performance. Two distributed sensing systems were developed to study the sensitivity, spatial resolution, measurement range, and response time. Through our research, we gained a full understanding of the design parameters and established the guidelines to optimize the system design and provide a suite of solutions for varieties of sensing applications in SHM.

3) Validate the new OCMI sensing technology for SHM. We have successfully proven the unique capability of OCMI for distributed crack detection, which is one of the most desired but lacking capability in SHM. We have successfully designed, fabricated and tested a polymer optical fiber based OCMI system for distributed large strain measurement. For the first time, a polymer fiber is used to detect and locate the cracks with high accuracy and high spatial resolution. In addition to polymer optical fibers, we have also successfully demonstrated other specialty fibers (e.g., single crystal sapphire fiber, and uncladded silica rods) based OCMI systems for distributed strain and high temperature measurements.

4) Innovate a new coherent microwave-photonic distributed sensing technology. In addition to the originally planned tasks, we have also extended our fundamental research into a new direction by looking into the general concept of coherent microwave-photonic interferometry (CMPI). Our theoretical analyses and experimental results have proven the extremely high sensitivity of CMPI, as well as the exciting capability of using CMPI for distributed dynamic measurement with the frequency of up to 20 kHz. This new innovation resulted in a breakthrough technology for monitoring the dynamic response, which have profound impacts on understanding the civil infrastructures under dynamic loading conditions such as seismic and acoustic waves.

Broader Impact

Although this particular project has focused on the design and demonstration of the new OCMI and CMPI based distributed strain sensing technology, the fundamental knowledge and the modeling/manufacturing/ interrogation methodologies developed in this research are transferrable to many other extended applications in SHM such as distributed monitoring of force, bending, fatigue and corrosion. In addition, the new OCMI and CMPI distributed sensing concepts could be modified to measure chemical and biological species, which may have numerous applications beyond SHM, such as pollution monitoring, environmental management and detection of chemical/biological warfare agents.

The fundamental studies in this project may promise a broader societal impact on human welfare and national security. The innovative idea of combining microwave and optics for sensing application and the successful demonstration of the OCMI and CMPI concepts will inspire similar interdisciplinary ideas, encourage broader participations of various disciplines in sensing research, and foster a wider range of collaborations.

This project resulted in 5 journal papers (3 more under various stages of preparation), 4 conference papers, 2 Ph.D. dissertation (Jie Huang, Leiwei Hua) completed and 1 Ph.D dissertation (Yang Song) to be completed soon. It provided interdisciplinary training (electrical, materails and civil engineering) for at least four Ph.D. students (Jie Huang, Baokai Cheng, Yang Song and Liwei Hua). Two of them are female engineering students.

Data Management

The optical and electrical signals of the developed sensors were recorded from the sensors. Microscopic images (both optical and SEM) of the fabricated sensors were taken. The sensors’ outputs in response to various controlled inputs (e.g., temperature, strain, bending of the beam, and vibrations) were recorded. The distributed sensor systems were tested under controlled inputs and the data were recorded in correlation with the inputs. Theoretical analyses and simulations were conducted and the results were summarized in graphics and tables. The simulations results were also analyzed with the experimental results.
